dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suburban Connecticut, outside of New York City, 1973. The still after a terrible storm. Trees dripping, their branc torn, the air warming just before the break of a new day. train lies dark and motionless, a few flashing yellow emergency lights up front, as a work crew removes debris the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various passengers, huddled uncomfortably, cold, asleep. On Paul Hood, 15-and-a-half, stoner-preppie look, hunched in his seat under the faint emergency exit light. He read his Fantastic Four comic book by the pale light of the emergency exit sign. Suddenly, the lights begin to flicker on and the hum of t train's engines returns. The conductor enters the car, blasting forth in his class nasal voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning ladies and gentlemen -- He sounds like a baseball announcer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling, ad lib) What ladies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- this train originating at New York's Grand Central Station is back in service - next stop will be New Canaan, Connecticut. New Canaan, Connecticut, next stop! He moves on to the next car. The train begins to move. Paul rubs his elbow against the window and looks out into still-dark early morning. He looks back down at his comic book. On the comic book: Reed Richards (also known as Stretch) zapped his young son with a cosmic ray gun to neutralize destructive energy that Annihilus has implanted in him.  The Thing, Medusa, Flame, and Richards' wife Sue Storm lo on, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DESTROYED THE WQRLD
dialogues.text: Paul looks up again, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In issue number 141 of The Fantastic Four, published in November 1973, Reed Richards has to use his anti-matter weapon on his own son, who Annihilus has turned into a human atom bomb. His son is the result of Richards' coupling with the earthling Sue Storm, and the problem is that the cosmic rays that infused Richards and the rest of the Fantastic Four on their aborted moon mission have made young Franklin a volatile mixture of matter and anti-matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train moves slowly through a suburban, semi-forested landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's what it is to come from a family, if you analyze it closely. Each of them is negative matter for the other ones. And that's what dying is -- dying is when your family, which is in fact your personal negative matter from which you emerge -- it's when the family takes you back, thus hurling you back into negative space... INT. TRAIN. CONT'D. On Paul, as the sun breaks over the horizon. His face glo warmly in the yellow light. He looks down idly at the com book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's a paradox -- the closer you're drawn back in, the further into the void you're thrown.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONRAIL STATION. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: The train slowly pulls in. The train doors open, and Paul, weary from the long night emerges. He sees his family gathered at the other end of platform -- Ben, 40, a bit worse for wear but still retai traces of his boyish looks; Elena, 37, distant and elegan even in her oversized sweater; and Wendy, 14, a sullen suburban Lolita. He pauses, regarding them. They stand, silent, even dignified, awaiting him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ST. PETER'S SCHOOL. MORNING
dialogues.text: To establish. A typical New England prep school.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PAUL AND FRANCIS'S DORM ROOM. MORNING
dialogues.text: Cramped, a mess, but quaint. Paul shares the room with Francis Davenport IV, a dissolute, smart-ass son of money Paul's alarm clock rings. He slams his hand down on it an jumps out of bed, fully clothed in his rumpled preppie uniform of frayed khakis, loose tie, shirt with one tail untucked in, etc. Across the room, Francis beckons from h desk, as he finishes loading up a four-foot-high bong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arise and shine, young Hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you changed the water in that bong from last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing a hit) The water, as you call it, is a special mixture of amaretto and Ben&Ben blended for just the exact chemical interaction with the last of our precious Thai stick. Paul reluctantly walks over and takes a hit. He coughs, spewing uninhaled smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waste not Master Hood -- that was $20 for the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering books, papers, almost talking to himself) Man, Francis, you are one drug addled elitist freak, and when the revolution comes I do not want to be lined up with you and shot, 'cause you're fucking ripe for political reeducation, you know, like in the fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, cancel your mental appointments, baby. What are you, like still stoned from last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spraying some chloroform mouth spray) I gotta get to English class.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ST PETERS' CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: An English class in progress. Paul Hood sits blankly, hardly listening, until he hears teacher call out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Libbets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Dostoyevsky is saying here is that to be a Christian is to choose, because you have to choose of your own choice, but since you can't choose to be good because that would be too rational you have to choose to be bad -- it's existential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Libbets, that's a very compelling summary, but -- Paul looks at her, smitten. Marge, Paul's friend, notices look.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ST. PETER'S HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: As class lets out, Paul accosts Libbets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Libbets. Hey, Dostoyevsky, I'm also really a fan, and what you were saying, you know, have you ever read The Idiot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Idiot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you liked Notes from Underground, you'll love The Idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to go) Great, thanks for the tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after her) The Idiot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ST. PETER'S HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Paul walks with Marge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love with Libbets Casey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you've been in love with like every other girl here, I was wondering when you'd get around to Libbets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beyond mere physical attraction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, because I don't think Libbets is capable of the sex act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truly? Do speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My diagnosis is messed in the head. A poor little rich girl -- I mean check out the jeans and fur look. And lend your ears to this brutality. Like her mom and step dad and her step-sisters are going to Switzerland to ski over Thanksgiving break -- and like they didn't invite her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did it last year too. It's like traditional or something. They've got this humongoid Park Ave apartment and she just holes up there with a wad of cash.  (beat) Aren't the hugely wealthy sad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) You think Francis is going to beat me to the punch here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since he sleeps with every girl you ever show an interest in, why don't you just keep your Libbets thing a secret from him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinking Marge.

dialogues.text: Paul, Francis and friends enter the dark, crowded room. Various kids are awkwardly dancing to some progressive fm style undanceable rock (Jethro Tull, etc.) Francis hands the tail end of a joint, but Paul waves it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more man. I'm about to drop as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya.

dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, let me enlighten you about something. You and I exist on two opposite sides of a great existential divide, that being your pathetic virginity on the one hand and my astonishing number of sexual conquests on the other. I'm off to get laid. See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flame on, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And remember, with your erogenous zones lubricated as such with the mighty herb, do not attempt terrestrial contact with members of the opposite sex -- because you drone on like a motherfucker when you're stoned. He waves his fingers toward Paul's eyes, in the classic "stoned" gesture, then wanders off. Paul looks on at the gathering. Marge waves to him from t dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul wanders, stoned, through the party. He sees Libbets across the room. She seems to be surrounded by friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul has cornered Libbets and is talking over the music. There are just a few people left, most of them making out with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stoned) -- because I've been reading Kerouac and Ginsberg and those guys were creating beat culture and traveling and sleeping wherever, and, of course, with all kinds of people, but when you read carefully the various contemporary accounts of their lives, and, uh, these guys didn't bathe much, I mean they were really filthy, with like genital crabs, lice, exceptionally strong body odor... Libbets smiles through her yawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you do that man?

dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. You're not planning --

dialogues.text: My man, I speak to you solely as a comrade in arms offering unconditional aid. I've been giving this one a lot of thought, and I believe that the two of you together might just reach that higher ground that -- A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hood, telephone. Paul rolls off his bed, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mess with Libbets. I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: INT. DORM HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul walks to the pay phone at the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.text: It's a modern (shag carpet, geometric-patterned wallpaper etc.) suburban house. Ben Hood talks on the phone, a drink in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

I think that most Americans do not like the idea of taping conversations and, frankly, it is not something that particularly appeals to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on for a second. (turning) Wendy, you want-to say hi to your brother? She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Watching what?

(still talking more to her father than into the phone) Dean told him on March 21st about Kalmback and Hunt, all about the payoffs to the Watergate burglars, so you tell me where the so-called "Dean Report" is, but you can't because it doesn't exist, because he lied about Haldeman and Erlichman and the April 17 tape, that's why! dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) OK, OK, the defense rests. (to Elena in the kitchen) Want another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you. We should be off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha. He puts the bottle back down without pouring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Hey Charles. Charles, calm down -- I wasn't in on it. Elena, putting on her coat, comes into the den and gives Wendy a kiss on the forehead as Wendy mumbles her good-by to Paul on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner's on the counter. We'll be at the Williams's -- you know the number.  (takes the phone from Wendy) Paul. Hi. Is there anything you'll want, any particular kind of food or snack or anything we can stock up on?... You're all right? ... OK. See you next week. I love you. Back to Nixon on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must recognize that one excess begets another, and that the extremes of violence in the 1960s contributed to the extremes of Watergate... On Wendy as she regards the TV, hearing her parents' farewells as they leave through the front door.

dialogues.text: Elena is sitting cross-legged, eyes closed, on her side o the bed. We hear the toilet flush from the master bath, a see Ben emerge in his boxers. He pauses in front of the b looking at Elena.

dialogues.text: (without opening her eyes) You're staring at me.

dialogues.text: (sighing) Sleep in the study? Please. Ben picks up a pillow and walks out, pausing wistfully at door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WENDY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wendy hears her parents' door close and sees a strip of l illuminate under her door as the hall light goes on, then off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MANHATTAN OFFICE BUILDING. DAY
dialogues.text: A nondescript, cleanly "modern" building. Engraved on the doors: "Shackley and Schwimmer, Securities Brokerage - Established 1964"

dialogues.speaker: INT. SHACKLEY AND SCHWIMMER CONFERENCE ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben, seated, is finishing a brief presentation to a small group of men, which includes George Clair, mid-thirties, unctuously handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what, exactly, is stagflation, this mixture of inflation and stagnation, and how should we in the securities industry understand and accommodate it? Well -- and I hope I'm not out of bounds here - think of the money supply as a large male organ, continuously inflating, and yet, the societal vaginal cavity simply wants more. As the vicious circle of higher returns without real satisfaction continues, the money-organ may seem to be in demand, but in fact even the most inflated capital is unwanted. This is why I suggest that while we engage this mawing abyss for the highest returns, we at the same time fantasize, so to speak, of the safe harbor of capital appreciation. The aging boss nods agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more or less mumbling) Brilliant, brilliant. George Clair just grins.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEN HOOD'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben is gathering papers, readying to leave. He looks up t see George Clair in his doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there Benjie, you're becoming quite the in-house philosopher. When do you have time to think up all that stuff -- Shackley sure eats it up.

dialogues.speaker: HALL IN FRONT OF BEN HOOD'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: As we see that Clair is deftly fondling Hood's attractive secretary as she is seated in the cubicle beside the door his office. She looks up coyly at Clair, hidden for the moment from Ben's view. Ben comes out of his office, pulling his coat on. Clair a the secretary pull back, but it's clear that Ben has some sense of what's transpiring between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, I'm just trying to get a global view of things -- can't just look at the small picture. There's an obvious rivalry between the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And speaking of which, you have those market share charts Mr. Shackley was asking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha George, not a problem. Tomorrow. Hey, you want to start covering the old filmed entertainment sector yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben you know that's your territory  - and I wouldn't dream to trespass  - you're the expert. Hey, how do you think Paramount's gonna do with that Blatty novel, what's it called? The Exorcist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overpriced bomb, cost over $6 million -- no stars, and no one's into the horror genre these days anyway. I'm advising the company recommend reducing positions there. It's disaster films that are gonna stay at the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant. Hey, you heading out a little early today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a meeting uptown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (already moving off) Right o'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up the organization! (then, to himself) Bastard. The secretary pretends not to hear.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UNIVERSITY CLUB. DAY
dialogues.text: An august New York institution. To establish.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLUB RESTAURANT. DAY
dialogues.text: A stuffy, Ivy League atmosphere. A decades-old tradition serving overcooked American food. Ben is seated across fr his father, Harold Hood, a retired curmudgeon. There is a walker parked by Harold's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waylaying a passing waiter)  I'd asked for that double martini about three hours ago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming right up, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So asking me out for lunch -- what prompted this exceptional event? -- Of course I'm paying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have to always go to your club, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why are you still calling me dad? You're forty years old already, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Well what am I supposed to call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's besides the point. The martini arrives, along with Ben's beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was actually trying to see about getting a little advice, you know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Advice? I'm supposed to be getting the stock tips from you, Ben. Unless - have you quit your job? They fired you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, dah-- He looks up and sees his father slurping his martini, not paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually it's not about work, it's advice about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for crying out loud Ben, you don't mean to tell me that your marriage is going down the drain now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Elena and I have kind of been talking, not really talking, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Your mother, God bless her, stood by me for forty-two years -- we never once contemplated divorce  - I assume you're talking here about divorce? The very thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But dad, you guys truly hated each other, I mean really hated each --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Waiter! Where's my cobb salad?  (back to Ben) You want advice Ben? If your big brother were still alive I'd have him go out into the back yard and beat some sense into your head. Look kid, you married that woman against my advice --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- What advice? You never --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's besides the point. The point is if I'd had any sense in me I'd have divorced your mother 40 years ago, and that's the truth, and here it is, 1972 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- 73, and divorce is as easy as paying off a traffic ticket, and for crying out loud, Ben, be a man and just get it over with. I would have if I'd had the chance. Ben ponders, as the food arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I -- well maybe I love her. Elena. His father rolls his eyes and stabs his salad with a fork

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ Ben! Make up your mind and eat your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOOK STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena browses the self-help section. A longish-haired, slightly gone-to-seed, but still handsome clergyman pause next to her. He's wearing an ecclesiastical collar and be bottoms. He pulls out a copy of Me, Myself and I, glancing again a Elena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena. Elena Hood, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Edwards. Philip Edwards. You came by and checked out the congregation a couple of times last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it was -- I ended up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) No need to make excuses --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEW CANAAN HIGH SCHOOL FIELD. DAY
dialogues.text: A cool gray afternoon. A group of boys are playing flag football on the field, while two groups of girls are gath underneath the bleachers at either end, warily smoking c1garettes. Wendy, Beth, and a couple of other girls are gathered in group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to one of the girls gathered in the other group) She said you licked Dave Brewster's weenie in the third floor bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a liar. I wouldn't touch Dave Brewster's dick if you paid me. It's probably crawling with v.d. after he put it in her, which he did. The conversation peters out at this point, as the two gro of girls give each other the hairy eyeball from afar. Wendy looks through from beneath the bleacher seats onto field where the boys are playing. A group of boys break from a huddle, Mikey among them. The quarterback takes the hike and Mikey runs out for a p As he runs, his breathing increases in volume, filling hi ears, and transforming into the humming sound he'd heard before. The quarterback spots him and throws a long one. He runs in an oblivion of beautiful white sound. The ball drops next to him as he continues, in a world of own, to run. Suddenly, the humming ends and he stops and turns around, see all the other kids just standing there looking at him One of them makes a pot-smoking gesture, as if that's the explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he returns to the group, ball in hand) Did anybody hear that? The other kids snicker. Wendy looks on, and catches Mikey eye for a fleeting moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go. She takes hold of her bicycle and pushes off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COFFEE SHOP. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena and Philip are seated at a booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a tremendously transformative year -- maybe a little controversial of course, but we're breaking down the old Unitarian barriers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose my reluctance was the group aspect of it -- I've never been much of a joiner, although I still consider myself a somewhat religious person --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I of course flatter myself that our church is not exactly what most people would call organized religion -- at times it's the disorganization that's liberating -- and of course I've begun to minister much more in what one might call therapeutic environments, in small groups, and one on one, couples -- Elena looks outside the window, and sees Wendy speed past her bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) My daughter. I haven't been on a bike for years. (still not really looking at him) When was the last time you rode a bike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit taken aback by the abrupt topic change) They say you never forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jarred back to his presence)  Forget what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget how to ride a bike. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course you don't, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy pulls her bike up to the back, locks it, and walks

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy moves with a certain amount of stealth through the aisles, arriving at the candy selection. She looks around. She takes a package of twinkies and slips them into the oversized pockets of her painter's pants. She turns around, and her breath goes out of her -- an OL WOMAN has been watching her shoplift. The woman looks sad at her, but says nothing. Wendy slowly walks past her and the back door of the store. The woman looks on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: As she walks her bike onto the sidewalk, Wendy comes acro Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey was looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? See ya. She pushes off on her bike. Sandy gazes after her. He takes his G.I. Joe out of his c pocket, and points it at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bam.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUBURBAN STREETS. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy flies along on her bike. It's a desolately beautifu fall day.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SILVER MEADOWS PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy rides by the front gates of the posh grounds of the private psychiatric clinic. A security guard leans agains booth. Once a bit past the gate, she gets off her bike and walks into a grove of trees near the front drive.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SILVER MEADOWS. DAY
dialogues.text: Mikey is waiting amid the trees next to his bike as Wendy arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some gum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (pulling them out of her pocket) Twinkie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens his mouth, displaying the gum on his tongue) I'm chewing. She puts the Twinkies back, and pops the gum in her mouth They stand together chewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Did you tell Sandy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Sandy? What? Wendy doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell him either, did you?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SILVER MEADOWS SWIMMING POOL. DAY
dialogues.text: The wind is picking up and the light is fading. Mikey and Wendy climb the fence around the pool, which is empty and half-covered in dead leaves and twigs. They climb down into the concrete recess and walk into th deep end, leaning against the far wall of the pool. They each matter-of-factly take their gum out and put it behind their ears. They begin not so much to kiss as to place their tongues each others' mouths. We see them from high above the pool, as the dead leaves swirl lightly around them, Mikey groping under Wendy's poncho.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILLIAMS HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: To establish.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS GUEST ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: A couple are in the final throes of lovemaking. We see Ja Williams's face, more or less enjoying the proceedings. T man gives a final heave and groan, and rolls off to revea himself to be -- Ben Hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janey smokes a cigarette. Ben is babbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were golfing, and you know, golfing to me is something I'm supposed to enjoy, and I was on the goddam golf team in college, so it's something one would assume I do well -- I used to do well -- but basically these days golfing for me is like hoeing, or plowing. Janey smiles briefly at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like farming. I am basically chewing up large tracts of expensively landscaped scenery with overpriced sticks, and George Clair has obviously, in the mere two years since he joined the firm, he has obviously been taking secret lessons with a golf pro, and I assume the entirety of his disposable income has been devoted to humiliating me on the golf course. And the guy talks - incessantly -- throughout the entirety of the miserable 18 holes  - on topics that are the supposed domain of my department --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) You're boring me. I have a husband. I don't particularly feel the need for another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a point there. That's a very good point. We're having an affair. Right. An explicitly sexual relationship. Your needs. My needs. You're absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should probably get dressed. The boys will be home soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha. She wraps a blanket around herself and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BACK OF WILLIAMS HOUSE. EVENING
dialogues.text: Ben cautiously walks out he back door and heads for the s gate.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD KITCHEN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Wendy enters the house as Elena is finishing supper preparations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Wendy. Without waiting for instructions, Wendy starts pulling ou plates and silverware and setting the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you on your bike today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mikey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey Williams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just riding around. Elena takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you looked very -- free -- when I saw you. Wendy continues setting the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weightless almost -- as if I were seeing my own memories of being a girl. There was something internal about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom. Are you ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy, of course. I'm sorry. You must think I'm ripe to be checked into Silver Meadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a psycho!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people at Silver Meadows aren't psychos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. They're rich drug addicts and celebrities. When I saw James Taylor there, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been through this Wendy  James Taylor was actually at that clinic up near Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I saw what I saw, and if you don't want to believe me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Wendy. Wendy frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need the money for my band uniform at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you quit the band - I never hear you practice anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really need to practice. I just play a few notes, you know, so I thought maybe I'd stay in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure your father and I would love to hear what you're playing these days. Maybe after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ben and Elena take their seats on the sofa. Wendy stands before them holding an enormous trombone, with a music st and sheet music in front of her. She puffs a series of seemingly disconnected notes in wal time. When she's done, she looks up from the sheet music to her parents. They applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't wait to see how it fits in with all the other instruments. Elena gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Elena is sorting through bills and writing checks at the kitchen table. Ben comes in and fills a glass with ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Halfords have invited us again this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it is a neighborhood tradition. He comes up behind her, looks down at the checkbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm, uh, going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rough day. Good night. He leans over and kisses her on the cheek. She sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a new aftershave? He recoils a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Musk, or something. You like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Good night. He walks uncertainly from the room. Does she suspect?

dialogues.speaker: INT. MIKE'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mikey is painfully at work writing an English essay. Sand comes to the door with a geometry textbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geometry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, anything but this English. Sandy puts the open textbook in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so good at math but not in English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not good at math. Just geometry. He looks at the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing out his examples on a piece of paper)  It's like, you know when they say "two squared"? And you think it means 2 times 2, equals 4? But really they really mean a square. A square with a side of two. And the area of the square is four. Like every time you use the word, like squared, or cubed, it's really space, it's not numbers, it's space. And it's perfect space, but only in your head, because you can't draw a perfect square, like in the material world, but in your mind, you can have perfect space. (pause) You know? As Mikey goes on, we see his geometric doodles, and hear faintly the HUMMING SOUND under his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I just need some help with my homework. A knock at the door. Jim stands in the doorway with a suitcase in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey guys, I'm back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honestly confused) You were gone? Sandy looks at Mikey as if pondering a lost cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look of disappointment)  Yeah Mikey. Yep, I was in Houston, working on some great new ideas about silicon, which comes from sand, very conductive. How you guys doing? How's school? Mikey's still flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I dunno. OK I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. Alright! He walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really didn't notice? Man, he's been gone for three days.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Janey is reading, still dressed, on the bed. She nods to as he enters with his suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good trip? He nods and puts his suitcase down, then sits heavily on side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he sits) You bet. It turns out it's a water bed, and his weight creates a w that nearly pushes Janey off her edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping up, which only creates another wave) Sorry honey. Hell, we've got to trade this thing in for a normal bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he begins to unpack) You notice anything with Mikey lately? The kid seemed a little out of it tonight, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight? Jim, he's been out of it since he was born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I guess he takes after me, huh? He laughs to himself. She gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COFFEE SHOP. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena and Philip Edwards are having coffee again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In many ways, the church-bound tradition of the father, son, and holy ghost is simply a version of the parent-child-adult triad within us all. It's a primitive set of symbols for our inner psychology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying that Christ is the child, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And God the angry parent, and the Spirit the hope of an integrated adult self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All well and good -- But tell me again what is it exactly that you believe in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask what the point is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Self-realization. Ministering to help people reach their fullest potential. Would you believe me if I told you I want you to see yourself reach your fullest potential and self-realization?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say it sounds like you're trying to get me into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's a potential you see yourself fulfilling... I mean...  (flustered) My, I sound a bit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That was stupid of me. I didn't mean to be so rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't. You actually, for some reason, you have the effect on me of making me feel just a tiny bit ashamed of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not too ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Now you are being rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're still trying to get me into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. Just then, Dorothy Franklin passes by their table, a smir firmly implanted on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello you two. Am I barging in on some kind of religious study group? Elena, you look marvelous. Will I see you and Ben at the Halford's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose we'll make an appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Reverend Edwards? Did you make the list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) I believe so Mrs. Franklin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the two of you there it will be positively a revival! I'm off! She scurries out of the coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid she's something of a gossip, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering her things to go) I'm afraid people around here provide her with quite a bit to gossip about.  (getting up) Take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I will indeed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLASSROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mikey is reading his English paper before the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of molecules we are connected to the outside world from our bodies. Like when you smell things, because when you smell a smell it's not really a smell, it's a part of the object that has come off of it -- molecules. So when you smell something bad, it's like in a way you're eating it. This is why you should not really smell things, in the same way that you don't eat everything in the world around you  - because as a smell, it gets inside of you. So the next time you go into the bathroom after someone else has been there, remember what kinds of molecules you are in fact eating. An embarrassed silence.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCHOOL MUSIC ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Band practice. The New Canaan High School band is doing a wind version of a popular rock tune. In front, there's Wendy, in halter top and hip-hugging be bottoms, incongruously blowing away on her trombone -- th being her one stab at extracurricular activities. In the flute section directly behind her is Sandy, piping away on a tiny piccolo. He sits on a riser slightly eleva above her. He directs downward at Wendy a protracted regard, a look intense concentration on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy's backside, her pants pushed outward in the back, affording Sandy a libido-charged view of the top of her b crack. Push in on a close-up of this cherished abstract landscap then back to Sandy's furrowed face.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CLUB RESTAURANT. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben and Harold are at their table again. Lunch is being cleared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the taxes I object to. It's all the fines and penalties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright dad. But you sold the house, you didn't tell anyone, including the IRS, and I'd of certainly liked to have seen if there was any old stuff --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was all junk! Another pause. Ben decides not to pursue an overworked to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Elena wanted to know when we could expect you on Thanksgiving. It's just going to be you this year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I'm going to Florida. I hate Thanksgiving and I hate the cold. I have a new nurse. She's a negro, she weighs three hundred pounds, and I've decided to leave my entire estate to her. Ben spits his drink out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Benjamin, you're still as gullible as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a joke? You don't tell jokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd start trying. If you don't mind. But I am going to Florida and I do have a new nurse.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Ben sits in the moving train, commuting home. He puts dow his paper to look at this fellow passengers. [NOTE: He is the same seat as was Paul at the beginning of the film.]

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD DEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena sits in a yoga pose.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD GARAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena enters the garage from the kitchen and turns the li on. She finds an old bicycle and pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUBURBAN STREETS. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena rides her bike into town, infused with the girlish sense of freedom she imagined for her daughter. Suddenly, there's a pop -- a tire is blown out. She slows down and gets off the bike. As she bends to look at the wheel, a station wagon slows near her. The driver's side window rolls open. It's Janey Williams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a lift?

dialogues.speaker: INT. JANEY'S CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena sits in the passenger seat. The two women are obvio uncomfortable with each other. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks again. For the dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for eating it. I don't know why I even pretend I can cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to know how to cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like we're too busy. They smile, barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of going back to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Social work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Educated guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm that predictable? No, you don't have to answer that. It's just that with the kids almost grown --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to apologize. I'm too much of a cynic. You actually seem to be trying to figure things out -- don't mind me. She pulls the car over.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIVE AND DIME STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: Janey's car pulls to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening her door) Thanks for the lift. If the bike's any bother--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None at all. I'll leave it in front of your garage. Happy Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena watches the car pull away. She turns and walks into store.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIVE AND DIME. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena moves through the aisles, putting various sundries a basket. She pauses in front of the lipsticks. She picks up a lipstick, looks at it, then quietly places in her pocket. We see her reflection in the security mirror above the ai as she quickly exits the store. The middle-aged lady behind the counter watches her leave

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIVE AND DIME. DAY
dialogues.text: In a wide shot, from across the street, we see Elena leav the store, followed by the shopkeeper who runs behind her taps her on the shoulder. They converse for a minute, and Elena is accompanied back into the store. Through the store windows we see her take the lipstick ou her purse. She's obviously distraught -- offering to pay, talking quickly, etc. The shopkeeper is holding a telepho not yet decided on whether to call her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To find yourself in the Negative Zone, as the Fantastic Four often do, means that all everyday assumptions are inverted -- even the invisible girl herself becomes visible, and so she loses the last semblance of her power.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. DAY
dialogues.text: Close on images from The Fantastic Four.

dialogues.speaker: KILLED
dialogues.text: Paul sits reading on his way home.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILLIAMS HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Janey pulls up in the driveway. As she gets out of the ca she hears a small explosion from the back of the house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD BACKYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Janey comes around the back to discover Sandy stuffing a model airplane with m-80 firecrackers. He lights them and runs back a safe distance. The plane explodes, its wrecka joining the debris from a few other dolls, models, and to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy! Sandy looks up -- busted. Janey marches over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little idiotic prick, you could blow yourself fucking sky high with all this demented crap. Sandy looks on the verge of tears. She softens and bends to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing) Hey. (picking up the firecrackers) I'll take this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You going to tell dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it matter? (sees something else lying on the ground) And what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffling) You know, it's the whip -- the one uncle Frank got me from Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not packed with explosives, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going into the house) Play with the whip.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mikey and Wendy are in front of the TV, watching a rerun Divorce Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Mrs. Williams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey, have you heard the explosions coming from the backyard? (he stares blankly at her) Do you know what Sandy's been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honestly oblivious, as usual) I dunno. She pauses, then walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILLIAMS BACKYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Sandy flicks his enormous whip in the direction of a smal bush. One by one, he snaps off its leaves.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAM KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Janey hauls a turkey out of a bag and into the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mikey and Wendy are still in front of the TV. Janey comes in again and looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you kids have homework?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up, in unison) Thanksgiving break. She walks out of the room again. Sandy comes in, whip in hand, looks over at Mikey and Wen then walks over to them, and, without a word, slumps down beside them and watches the TV.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena walks unsteadily, pausing to rest against a brick w She takes a deep breath, then walks to a corner where a l taxi station wagon sits idling. She gestures to the drive who beckons her in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Later, still mentally devolving in front of the TV, but w various junk food detritus surrounding them and a differe show, a rerun of the original Highway Patrol. Sandy wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Wendy gets up, goes upstairs, and wanders down the hall t the bathroom. She gets to the door just as Sandy gets there from the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you. Sandy hesitantly opens the door, as Wendy still hovers by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Sandy, what were you blowing up out there? Your mom was pretty p.o.'d.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my model planes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones you built?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were old. And they couldn't fly anyhow. I'm going to get a radio-controlled airplane at Christmas, and then I'll stuff it full of m-80s and then fly it into Mrs. Burgess's English class and blow it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But he stays put, unaware it seems that he's blocking the doorway. Wendy looks around -- no one in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you mine if you show me yours. Sandy goes wide eyed, and almost against his will backs i the bathroom like a feather.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mikey looks up from the TV, wondering where Wendy is. He another Pringle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS BATHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy flips up her dress for Sandy. He slowly unzips, his hand unsteady. We can tell from the look on Wendy's face that she's feeling a bit sorry for t little guy. Suddenly Sandy turns beet red, and bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?! What do you want? Get out! Get out of here! The door flips open -- and Janey Williams appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sizing up the situation)  Shit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MASTER BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Janey is giving Wendy a lecture

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A person's body is his temple, Wendy. This body is your first and last possession. Now as your own parents have probably told you, in adolescence our bodies tend to betray us. That's why, in Samoa and in other developing nations, adolescents are sent out into the woods, unarmed, and they don't come back until they've learned a thing or two.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS HOUSE DOORWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy is led to the door by Mrs. Williams. Wendy trades a glance with a sullen Mikey, who sits in th living room pretending to ignore her.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy walks her bike with the wind in her face. From behind her, Mikey rides up on his bike and rides alongside her. She doesn't look at him. Trying to stay on his bike, but moving slowly, he wobbles nearly falling off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't ever want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why'd you come after me?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up. Elena gets out and pays the driver.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben is in front of the open freezer, trying to get someth out. He hears Elena come in the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena. I need some help here if this thing's gonna defrost by tomorrow. She comes up and together they tug and pull until they succeced in extracting a large, frozen turkey. As they pu it out, it slips from their hands and, after a dull thump slides along the floor. They smile. Elena bends over to pick it up. Ben observes her. She not his look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. He goes over and picks up the turkey, placing it in the s He looks back at her and notices her vaguely distraught l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sure, I -- Did you remember to pick up the cranberry sauce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yes. They stand together, his concern and her vulnerability forming an awkward attraction between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you like it on your turkey sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. I'm -- are you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I think I am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) You know Elena, I've been thinking--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, maybe no talking right now? If you start talking, you're going to-- She kisses him as if she needed him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben and Elena enter their bedroom. Elena closes the door quietly behind her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben and Elena undress shyly. They make love. Elena's face is almost fearful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena and Ben lie in bed side by side in the pale afterno light. Neither speaks. Ben turns on his side, and notices small tear forming in Elena's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just sad Ben -- I mean it was... you were, but, you know. I just don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently making light) Whatever that means Elena -- And you complain about me not communicating... I thought it was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't mean to sound negative. It was -- But Ben.  (beat) What is going to happen with us? Have you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to bring this up now? What? Did I do something here? Is that it? Is it something I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't accusing you, Ben. It's just that we've got to be honest. Not just with ourselves, but with the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, sitting up) Hell, I know. I -- I guess if you want to accuse me, you've got -- (looks at watch) Oh hell! I've got to pick up Paul. I almost forgot. He gets up and starts to get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were saying? He smells the armpits of the shirt he's putting on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yikes -- I was hoping to wear this thing to the Halford's Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That shirt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it -- I'll wash it for you. He looks at her ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy walks and Mikey rides along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to follow me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. I -- They're now in front of the Hood's house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben exits the house in a rush, and sees Wendy and Mikey o the street in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there Mikey, how's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tripping off of his bike) Business? Uh, I dunno. Ben grimaces, fiddles for his car keys. As Mikey remounts and rides off, Wendy passes her father the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm picking up Paul at the station  - want to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you been up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD LIVING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy enters the house and climbs the stairs. She sees the crumpled bed sheets in her parents' room and hears Elena in the shower.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NEW CANAAN STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: Paul walks to the parking lot with his father, who carrie his duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREETS. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben's car heading back to the house with Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's school treating you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grades?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone special? You know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hnnn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's good to see you -- we miss you around the house and all, but this St. Peter's, it's top of the line, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Paul, I've been thinking, maybe this is as good a time as any to have a little talk, you know, about -- well -- He makes a sharp turn. Paul puts his arms up on the dashb to steady himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) About?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the whole gamut. Facts of life and all. Some fatherly advice, because, I tell you, there's things happening that you're probably old enough... well... (pause) For example, on the self-abuse front -- now this is important - it's not advisable to do it in the shower -- it wastes water and electricity and because we all expect you to be doing it there in any case -- and, um, not onto the linen, and not on your sister's underwear or any clothing belonging to your mother -- He pauses to gauge the effect of his monologue on his son then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Dad -- Just then Ben runs a stop sign and almost slams into anot car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy! Well. If you're worried about anything, just feel free to ask, and, uh, we can look it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, dad, you know I'm 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the more reason for this little heart to heart... great.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: The car pulls up. Paul gets out, looking shell-shocked. H sees Wendy waving to him from a second floor window. He n back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Paul. On second thought, can you do me a favor and pretend I never said any of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. In the doorway, Elena waits.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Paul knocks on Wendy's bedroom door. She opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings, Charles.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WENDY'S ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Paul and Wendy sit on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are the parental units functioning these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's like doing his Up With People routine, mom hasn't been saying much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Dad seems a little weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well wait till mom opens her mouth. They both ponder silently. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I operate your telephonic apparatus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you use the phone downstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calling an individual, Charles, in New York. Confirming a social outing for Friday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a one-on-one kind of date thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her name's Libbets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Libbets? What kind of a name is Libbets?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Morning. To establish.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD BEDROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Elena is coming out of the master bathroom in a robe, a t wrapped around her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The turkey in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuffed and baking.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD HALLWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Ben Hood pads down the hall in his bathrobe, tries the bathroom door. It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone home?

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD BATHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: The shower is running, but Paul is standing by the open window, puffing on a joint and trying to blow the smoke outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be out in a second. Ben walks back to the bedroom, smirking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you will.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD DINING ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: One by one, each member of the Hood carried in a final it to place on the overstuffed Thanksgiving table. Then, one one, they each silently take their seats. They look over the table. No one moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's great we can all be together. And this Thanksgiving, no hysteria, no yelling, especially with grandpa not here, although we miss him. So let's do it right and actually, Wendy, why don't you say grace. You used to love to say grace, remember. Wendy grimaces, as they all bow their heads slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, thank you for Thanksgiving, and for letting us white people kill all the Indians... Everyone looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and steal their tribal lands and stuff ourselves like pigs Mutterings and groans: "Wendy!" "For Christ's sake" etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... while children in Africa and Asia are napalmed and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus all right enough! They all unceremoniously start to dig in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS GUEST ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Janey Williams is pouring Benjamin Hood a drink from a bo of vodka. Benjamin is already unbuttoned and shoeless; Ja still fully dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the Thanksgiving I had, I need it. You having one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a bit. She sits next to him, he kisses the back of her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think Elena might suspect something. Janey gives him a rather contemptuous look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking aloud) Maybe it's all for the better, you know? Yesterday, at dinner, well, she hasn't said anything... has she acted funny to you, I mean, have you noticed anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost ironic) Have I noticed anything? I'm not married to her Benjamin, you are. I think you've probably a better vantage point from which to observe her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, I -- I've been working a lot lately, and -- No, that's not it. I guess we've just been on the verge of saying something, whatever it is, just saying something to each other. On the verge. Janey gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back. Benjamin looks at her quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birth control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Gotcha. She leaves the room. He leans back onto the bed. Sits back up. Takes a sip of vodka. Puts the glass down. Takes his socks off. He's now just his jockey shorts and shirt. Faintly, he hears a door close. The front door? He takes another sip. He hears another sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janey? Nothing. He goes to the door and carefully opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Janey? He hears, quite audibly, a car door open, close, Janey's start and pull out. He runs to a front window just in time to catch a glimpse her driving off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUEST ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Benjamin sits on the guest bed, still in his underwear, drinking from the bottle. He gets up and starts to wander around the house, still holding the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin saunters through. He presses on the king-sized b it undulates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water bed! Dig it! He wiggles comically, making more waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben idly goes through Janey's drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rifles through the bathroom cabinet, checking out the medicines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices a garter belt hanging from the walk-in closet door. He picks it up and twirls it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin walks in, an obvious look of distaste. He sorts through a few of Mike's things -- monster eyes t glow in the dark, The Sensuous Woman, etc. He twirls the garter belt absentmindedly, then tosses it the back of Mike's closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finishes putting his clothes back on. As he reaches fo the door, he hears voices and quickly steps back in again Teenage voices. Mikey and Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, no one's here. Maybe you want to go to the basement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can just watch some TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a TV in the basement. Hood hears their steps down into the basement.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BASEMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy and Mikey stand in the middle of the semi-lit basem

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can mess around. You know, only if you want to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you -- with Sandy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like him? He worships you. But Wendy doesn't seem to hear -- she's drawn to an objec lying next to a bean bag chair off to one side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's this? With a look of utter fascination, she picks up a Nixon ma looking at it as though it were an archeological find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy! She puts the mask on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from behind the mask) I won't take my pants off. But I'll touch it. That's as far as it goes. Mikey looks totally confused. Remaining fully clothed, Wendy loosens Mike's belt, showi no excitement from behind her mask, and lets him climb on of her for a dry hump. Just then, a shaft of light hits them from the top of the stairs -- Ben towers above them, looking down. Mikey flips over immediately and pulls his clothes togeth grabbing a TV Guide as Wendy stands up, the mask still on As Ben descends Mikey, still stuffing his shirt-tail into pants, pretends to flip through the TV Guide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) When worlds collide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4:30 movie. When Worlds Collide. Ben arrives, folds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you kids doing down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think we're doing, dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I think? I think you're probably touching each other. I think you're touching that reckless jerk-off, for god's sake, and I think he's trying to get into your slacks. I think, at fourteen years of age, that you're getting ready to give up your girlhood --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hang on there, Mr. Hood --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you direct a single word at me, Mikey. I don't want to hear it. I'll be speaking with your parents about this situation very soon. Bet your ass on that, son. Young lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking to me, dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else would I be talking to? And take that thing off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling off the mask) Well, then forget all this stern dad stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in your smart ass remarks now, lady. Let's go. Right now. You and I can discuss it on the walk home. She stands next to Mikey for a moment, both on the verge tears.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. EVENING
dialogues.text: Hood and Wendy walk through a cold drizzling rain. He looks at her from time to time, then takes her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, kiddo, don't worry about it. I really don't care that much. I'm just not sure he's good enough, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, he's not serious, he'll end up living off Janey and Jim, you watch. It's just that you develop a sense when you get older, if things are going to work out or if they won't, and sometimes it's not worth the mess... She looks at him. They keep walking. She walks through a puddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your toes cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He stops and lifts her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll carry you up the drive. She puts her arms around his neck and he lifts her up. On her face, as he carries her -- a look of blank but rea intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD FRONT HALL. EVENING
dialogues.text: Hood and Wendy enter, wet and cold, muttering hellos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen) Dinner in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go dry off now. Wendy heads for the stairs, Hood following.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD BEDROOM. EVENING
dialogues.text: Hood finishes taking off his wet clothes as Elena enters turns on a light. She stands watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never guess where I found her. Not much response From Elena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the basement over at Janey and Jim's. With that weirdo Mikey. Not even a TV on. And they're on the floor and he's got his trousers down though thank goodness she's still dressed. Well, I really let him have it!  (a nervous laugh) ... and Wendy came home peacefully... Hey, should I dress for the Halford's now, or - give me your -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to you. I'd like to go early and leave pretty soon after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get you loud and clear... hey, you look nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what were you doing in the Williams' basement anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just dropping off a coffee cup. Jim left it, last time he was over. It was on the dash of the car. You were, you know, reading, thought I'd just catch some air. Let's eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh right. The mustache coffee cup. The one that was sitting on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one. She walks down to the kitchen, Benjamin following her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Wendy is already in the kitchen, fishing through the draw for silverware and napkins. Paul enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be on the 10:30 train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah let the guy have his fun. What's the name of this girl with the Park Avenue address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Libbets. Libbets Casey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Libbets? What kind of name is Libbets?

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A silent dinner of turkey sandwiches with Elena, Benjamin and Wendy. The turkey carcass sits, embarrassed, in the middle of the table. Wendy, finished, gets up from the table. Opens the fridge but finds nothing. Then goes to the candy shelf and grabs some Hot Tamales, leaving the room without a word and goi into the den.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wendy turns the TV on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that ends today's highlight coverage of the Watergate affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hood and Elena rise from the table with their dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's for dessert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No advice from the experts, huh? His plate slips out of his hands into the trash. He fishe out and sets it on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind? Don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't make a pleasant evening, if that's what you're after. I don't want to talk about it. Stupid mustache cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena, what are you're talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Elena, if you're gonna pull that passive aggressive stuff on me again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your unfaithfulness -- that's what I'm trying to talk about. Your unfaithfulness. Your betrayal. Your dalliance. And you won't do me the dignity of being up front about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quieter) Am I unfaithful? Is that what you're trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a starting place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what kind of faithfulness are you after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're going to insult me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else could I be? What else could I be? We're not living in the real world here. You're living out some fantasy land from the past, or some advice or something from those psychoanalysts... there are some hard facts here. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the law of the land... the government, the world, those two guys on the Yankees... And I'm not having any fun at it, I can tell you that. I'm not...

dialogues.speaker: INT. DEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wendy puts the volume of the TV up, to drown out a conversation she can almost overhear but doesn't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh lord. You think I'm so dense. And now you want to be seen with your dense wife at the cocktail party. You want to wear that ridiculous shirt which doesn't go with those pants at all. You want to wear that, and you want me to shake hands with your friends and make conversation and dress up in an outfit that shows a lot of cleavage and you're not going to accord me the respect of talking honestly about this... You don't really know what this feels like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Sure I do. Do I know what loneliness feels like? Sure I do. I know a lot about it, if that's what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjamin. That's supposed to explain it? Seemingly tired, he stands before her. Silence. Elena sig then walks into the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to the Halford's. The number's on the calendar in the kitchen. We should be home around 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes still glued to the

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: Is it a big party? A big neighborhood party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just curious. If there's a problem, I guess I'll just call you there to interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of problems are you planning exactly? Elena kisses the top of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still watching the TV) Oh I thought I'd steal the station wagon, drive up to a commune. Or set the house on fire. You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just bundle up. It's supposed to freeze tonight. We'll see you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOD HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Elena and Ben emerge from the house, and look up at a darkening, foreboding sky. A light rain falls. They jog toward their car.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. HOOD CAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The car moves slowly through the rainy suburban streets. Inside, Elena and Ben don't speak.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HALFORD HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Their Firebird pulls up. There are already many other car parked on the lawn and driveway.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALFORD FOYER. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hood and Elena enter. Dot Halford accosts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, Elena. Wonderful! Wonderful! So wonderful to see you. Finishing the last of a celery canoe, she kisses the air to Ben's ear and gives Elena a manic hug. Then, picking up a white salad bowl from the hall table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care to play? New this year. Close on: the bowl full of keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strictly volunteer, of course. You can put your coats in the library if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, damn. Uh, I've left the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Yeah, we'll be right back, Dot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben and Elena climb back in the car and close the doors, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This just isn't the best moment for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know. I had no idea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That this was going to be a key party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, if we'd understood we could have invented some kind of excuse. A key party -- did you see how stuffed that bowl was already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
