dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're here and we don't have to stay -- we ought simply to put in an appearance and then we can head home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it, Ben --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not staying at this party so we can go home with someone else's wife. That's not why we're here, right? We're simply being neighbors here, and I think we should do just that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have some marker, that's what I think, if you want to know the truth. You have some marker and you're going to put it on the house keys so that Janey can find them and then when I get back to the house I'll find the two of you in there and Wendy'll be able to hear you and Paul will be back and he'll hear you and I'll catch you, that's what I think. She'll be swearing and banging against the wall and I'll catch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena. She rubs her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena, it's not what you think. It's not a big plot. Honestly. Honestly. I don't know if you want to go over this now, but it's just something that comes over me. I don't feel good about it. I know I've done what I didn't want to do. I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm really pleased to hear a confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena, you're just getting wound up to get wound up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the diagnosis, Ben. Thank you. So let's just go to this fiasco if that's what you want to do. Let's just go on in. I'd rather talk to anyone else but you. She pulls the keys out of the ignition, gets out of the c and slams the door. He follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dot! Elena, entering the house again, tosses the keys at Dot Halford, who looks surprised. Hood slides in behind his wife. Dot drops the keys into the bowl. Slow-motion, close up: the keys, on their equine chain, f in with a THUNDEROUS CRASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is crowded with nervous, expectant couples and various groupings. Elena slips into a side room. Benjamin heads over immediately to the drink table and po a stiff one, turning around to find at his elbow none oth than George Clair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clair, George Clair! What the hell brings you to New Canaan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's the funniest thing. I've been talking to some investors -- a little outside venture, you understand, between you and me -- about a scheme to manufacture a new Styrofoam packaging. Little peanut like pieces that can really keep an item free from trauma during shipping. Miraculous. Anyway, it turns out the genius behind the whole project is your neighbor, Jim Williams. How about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hey, isn't that a one-in-a million coincidence. A real dreamer, Jim Williams, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darned right. Look here, Benj, whaddya make of this sequel to The Godfather? You think it's gonna work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't see how. I think the public's had its fill of this gangster stuff. No, trust me -- disaster pics. And air hockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, good. Benjamin catches a glimpse of Janey, voluptuously attired across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gonna make a break for the hors d'oeuvres guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, see you bright and early Monday am. (beat) Say, where's the wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking as he goes) In Rhode Island with the folks. I'm a free agent tonight. At this, they both notice Elena slowly gliding across the other side of the room. Clair gives Ben a sideways glance then moves on. Ben makes straight for Janey, who pretends to be preoccup with a plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh jeez, Benjie. Well, here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right, but where the hell were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering, but too loudly) Don't bullshit me around, Janey. Jesus Christ, I waited around for more than half an hour, in nothing but my boxer shorts, and -- and what's all that about? What the hell happened? Janey takes a sip of her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prior engagement overcame me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Benjamin Hood. I have obligations that precede your... from before you showed up. One or two, you know, good-natured encounters, that doesn't mean I'm... I'm not just some toy for you. When I remembered some chores I wanted to get done before the party, I just did them, that's all, because I wanted to do them before I saw Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy? Jimmy? I don't know how to take this. And what do you mean, Jimmy? I thought you said you and your husband --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you take it isn't all that interesting to me, Benjamin. I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't believe you could be so -- Stalling, he watches her take another sip of her drink an wander off. The air is filled with talk of Watergate, Billie Jean Kin the Oil Crisis, the Mets. Benjamin goes over to the couch, where Dave Gorman is chatting up an attractive younger woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting up a joint) Welcome to the Monkey House has been a seminal influence on me -- hey Benjamin -- give it a try? This stuff will make some sense out of those larger questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving it away) Thanks for the advice Dave. But then, Benjamin changes his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well, what the hey... Taking the joint, he tugs on it, holding the smoke in his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coughing) Good shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure is good shit. It's opiated. I had it in my chamber for a while. I was smoking this other --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fret, Benjie, it's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darn it, Dave. He rises unsteadily, weaving through the room's conversations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take California. They've got their own airline in-state that's not subject to the fare controls. Compare Sacramento to L.A. on the controlled airlines and you'll see what Friedman is saying -- supply and demand, less restriction. Benjamin walks over to a window. The outdoor lamps illumi a new and heavy downpour of frozen sleet.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONRAIL TRAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul is seated, reading the latest number of The Fantasti Four comic book. The cover displays a lurid, atomically glowing baby. The conductor walks through the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approaching our final stop, Grand Central Station. Paul looks out the window at the tenements of Harlem, bar visible through the walls of sleet. Soon the train enters tunnel toward the station.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARK AVENUE APARTMENT BUILDING. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul gets out of a cab and heads inside. He's met by the doorman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Libbets Casey, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smirk) Elevator on the right. Eighth floor -- she's waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL IN FRONT OF LIBBETS' APARTMENT DOOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the other side of the door) Open it Paul! Paul opens the door, and enters the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBBETS' APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: It's half dark, has an air of old wealth. Libbets skids across the parquet floor to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. We were waiting! She turns and runs into the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) We? And there, in the den, cleaning an ounce of dope on an op copy of Nixon's Six Crises, is -- Francis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting the book up) You oughtta read this Hood, Nixon, our leader, all ye need know about the travails of life. Check out the Checkers speech stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all hope drained from him)  Francis. You gonna leave the seeds in there? In the binding like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All will be revealed, baby. The television is turned on to a weather report about the coming ice storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome sleet and rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy there. You, young knight. Can you check on the mead? Can you sally forth and secure us some more mead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nasal voice, impersonating a TV character) Moisture! Moisture!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) Beer. In the pantry. Paul trudges disconsolately out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBBETS KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul, after wandering a maze of halls, enters the kitchen where he takes a six-pack out of the fridge and returns t the living room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBBETS LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: He enters the room with the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie opens them with his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a beer) Hey, it's a sellable skill. Francis licks closed a second joint, then takes the beer opens it with his rear molars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell on the fillings. Paul opens the other two beers and hands one to Libbets. light up a joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's gonna freeze, the big freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Paul, are you gonna get home okay? Paul and Francis exchange a look. She puts an Allman Brothers tape on the 8-track and turns TV down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD BATHROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: Wendy enters the bathroom. She fills the sink with water, then turns off the tap. Sh takes a razor blade from the counter, and slowly, determinedly, holds it to her wrist. She presses it into her skin, drawing a small drop of blo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch! She drops the blade and splashes water on her wrist, grab some toilet paper and holding it against the tiny wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid. She hears the phone ring and walks downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD DEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wendy picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hood residence.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mikey is on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're parents at that party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. Can't really tell yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I got you into trouble. Maybe we don't have to, you know... unless you really want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Silver Meadow, check out the ice storm... You wanna come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. OK.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mikey, bundled up in a huge orange ski parka and cap, hea for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's freezing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing) Yeah. When it freezes, I guess that means the molecules are not moving. So when you breathe, there's nothing in the air, you know, to breathe in to your body. The molecules have stopped. So it's clean. Sandy just looks at him. He walks out into the night.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALFORD'S. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Elena sits on a couch, talking to no one, barely looking when someone stands in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Edwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you might find it in your heart to call me Philip? He sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're here... I'm a bit surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes the shepherd needs the company of the sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to try hard not to understand the implications of that simile. Philip's about to reply, but thinks better of it. They sit glumly next to each other for a minute. Then Phi rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. He walks swiftly to the hall and hurriedly fishes his key out of the bowl, then heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passing by) I hope those weren't my keys. He laughs at his own joke as Philip rushes out the front door. Back to Elena, even more forlorn than before.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBBETS APARTMENT BATHROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul enters the bathroom. We hear Francis' and Libbets' voices from the other room, laughing. He pees. At the sink, he pauses in front of the medicine cabinet, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eureka. He pulls out some bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valium. Seconal. Uh, (can't quite pronounce this one) Par-er-goric? (a beat, looking into the mirror for effect) Francis Chamberlain Davenport the Fourth -- tonight you sleep the sleep of the just. He pockets the Seconal and turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBBETS APARTMENT DEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Paul re-enters the den to find Francis alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And whence has yon virginal maiden absconded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like into one of the other 20 or so bathrooms they've got in this place. Paul takes out the bottle and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it out. Not for the faint of heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pharmaceutical! You are a god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up beer, trying to hurry before Libbets returns) One for you and one for me. He hands a pill to Francis, then pretends to pop one into mouth and takes a swig of his beer. As Francis downs his Paul pockets his unswallowed pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the doorway) No candy for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groovy. (to Paul) Young master of the revels, a treat for our hostess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, I don't, it's really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Paulie, share the wealth. You copped 'em from her mom's stash anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hand in pocket) Libbets, you really shouldn't mix and match, you know with the beer. I'll put 'em back. Libbets reaches into his pocket and pulls out the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh far out, Paulie. Hey look, these expired like five months ago. You think they're better aged? She opens up the bottle and takes one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should have just a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice dad. She takes the pill. Paul looks on, thwarted.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALFORD'S. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ben is back at the bar, pouring another tall one. Mark Bo sidles up next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benjie, feeling no pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Indian saying goes, pain is merely an opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding across the room) Hey -- check it out. Maria Conrad's brought her son. (walking off) I wish some of the gang had brought their daughters! Ben feels a wave of distaste at the joke. He looks across the room as Maria and her son Neil (strin hair, acne, tie-dyed turtleneck, patched jeans) are engag Janey and Philip Edwards in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIBBETS' APARTMENT. NIGHT

dialogues.text: Libbets and Paul in the same position whence last we saw them. Paul delicately leans to one side of the couch and picks phone. He dials a number.

dialogues.text: Wendy emerges from the house and gets on her bike, but th ice makes it too slippery. The storm is now in full swing She gets off and walks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wendy walks, barely keeping her balance in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALFORD'S NIGHT
dialogues.text: All the couples are now gathered for the key selection process, men on one side of the room, women on the other. storm can be heard outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what shall the order be, alphabetical? In order of appearance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Golf handicap! Lowest handicap does the honors. Nervous laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Golf handicap? Ladies, isn't it up to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I'll go first, damn it. Let's just line up and get it over with. Maria chooses Stephen Earle. Hands the keys to him. A smattering of applause as she takes his arm and they leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck! Neil watches his mother's exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

Ben lo on, momentarily triumphant. Elena smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my own husband. Isn't that against the rules?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Oh, I think not. Mr. Gadd smiles as they leave, obviously happy to go. Finally, only Mark Boland, Neil Conrad, Janey and Jim Williams, Rob and Dot Halford, Sari Steele, Benjamin and Elena.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting down to the wire! Elena steps forward. Benjamin is obviously agitated. Close on Janey's hands selecting -- away from Ben's equin key ring. Ben suddenly lurches forward, semi-drunkenly, trying to separate Neil from Janey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ad lib) Hey hey Ben, hang on there a sec. He backs off, ashamed, and, taking a step backwards, trip over the coffee table. Mark Boland helps lift him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... maybe I should... the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right down the hall, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Sorry, I'm sorry. Uh, I'll be back. Dot follows Mark Boland down the hall behind Ben. Suddenly, it's just Elena and Jim Williams, and Sari Stee and Rob Halford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Sari's arm) Actually, we didn't put our keys in at all. But you won't spread it around? It's my party, and Dot isn't... hey, we're just going to slip upstairs for a while. You folks like a cup of coffee or something before we go? Elena and Jim look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob, we'll fix it for ourselves. You two go and get acquainted. We'll let ourselves out the front door. Jim and Elena stand there alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have to say I don't have much faith that my car keys are still in that bowl. Doesn't seem entirely safe, leaving your car keys around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me. She takes the bowl and dips her hand in. Two sets are lef One, her own, she avoids. She takes out Jim's keys and wa across the room, handing them to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but -- oh, I don't think so. It's been kind of a discouraging evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't have hoped for much better when you came up the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow it was different in my imagination when I thought about it. Actually, I didn't think about it at all, really. They sit down on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want coffee or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe they have one of those filter jobs in the kitchen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Elena, the fact that we're neighbors... you know, close friends, well it sort of makes this a little strange, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband is probably passed out in the bathroom, or at least he wishes he were. I've been married to him for 17 years and I don't have any intention of going in there to get him... so what I'm proposing is that since your wife has gone off with a boy, and since you are standing here alone, I'm proposing that you and I do what makes sense. Stay warm. Pass some time. That's all. They both look at their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't make me feel as if I'm being too forward, OK? If you don't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hey. Let's go for a drive.

dialogues.text: Okay. Shall we clean up around here first? Do you think it's all right--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, that wasn't in the contract. But they still walk around turning off lights. In the hallway, Elena looks a bit mournfully at the light seeping from underneath the bathroom door. She hears the sound of running water from inside. Then she goes into a sideroom and joins Jim. They pick up their coats.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HALFORD HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Elena and Jim walk outside into the freezing, pelting rai Covering their faces, they jog to his car, an oversized Cadillac. A thick glaze of ice forms on his windshield.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JIM'S CADILLAC. NIGHT
dialogues.text: They climb in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to defrost this thing for a while. He turns on the ignition, and the vents start to blow col air at them. He leans over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do these seats go back? That starts it. He jumps at her, unbuckling her and unzip himself. They tangle uncomfortably for a few seconds. And then, comically, he's in her. With a groan, it's over in a flash. Jim pulls himself off, readjusting his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was awful, really awful. I'm so sorry, Elena. Elena has somehow worked herself into the cavity of the g compartment, and is trying to figure out how to extricate herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are really rotten at home. You wouldn't believe how rotten. Janey's sick. She's unstable, I guess... it's not the right time to tell you... but that's it -- it's like I can't make her happy, the boys can't make her happy, she just doesn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, maybe we should just go. I've got to look in on the kids. Paul is supposed to be coming back in from the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, let me make it up to you -- I can do better than that, honestly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine. I wouldn't expect you to see it any other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you just need -- look, can you wait here a sec, I need to tidy up -- just a minute, I'll be right back. You'll wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. She opens the door and walks back to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena hesitantly walks to the bathroom. She opens the door. Ben's sitting on the floor, next to t toilet, woozily flipping through the pages of a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena.

dialogues.text: Ben, I've got a ride home. Maybe you should sleep this one off on the couch here?

dialogues.text: I'll drive you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben. She sits on the toilet next to him, stroking his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in no condition to drive. We'll talk in the morning, OK? He sits, accepting and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get some sleep on the couch out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up at her, with gratitude) Sure. I'll try. And we'll talk in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILLIAMS HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wendy walks up the drive in the rain, pauses, then goes t the front door and knocks lightly. The door swings ajar. pushes on it, and lets herself in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone home? Hello. Wendy wanders into the living room, then climbs the steps The sound of the wind and the darkness begin to scare her She goes into Mikey's room -- it's even more of a disaste zone than usual. She sees on the wall his dark-light poster of the 12 (sex positions of the zodiac. dialogues.text: Wendy. She gives out a little yelp.

dialogues.text: Elena gets in. They drive off silently.

dialogues.text: The car moves haltingly through the sleet and ice, inches a hill, then falters and slides back silently, circling a couple of times before crashing into an embankment.

dialogues.text: As the car slides and crashes amid Jim's and Elena's scre Silence.

dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.text: Jim and Elena get out, shaky, from the car. They pause for a moment. The street lamp above them sizzles, but stays on. They start to walk.

dialogues.text: Paul and Libbets, still frozen in the same position. Fina Paul gently pushes Libbets' head back. It slides off his leg and, as Paul lurches forward in a failed attempt to grab it, Libbets flops backwards, her h hitting the carpet with a dull but decidedly loud thump.

dialogues.text: Oh shit oh shit. He grabs his comic books and runs for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Can I get into your bed?  (pause) With you? Sandy begins to shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about them. They're at that party, getting drunk and falling all over each other and making jokes about McGovern and stuff. Sandy begins to cry.

dialogues.text: It's just -- it's just -- She takes his hand, and they walk out of the room and dow the hall, into the guest room.

dialogues.text: Wendy and Sandy enter. She sees the vodka bottle on the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vodka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never tasted the stuff? She fills the glass to the brim and hands the bottle to Sandy. They clink and each toss back a sip -- Wendy almost the entire glass. Sandy coughs and gags, but swallows.

dialogues.text: Try again. He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more shot?

dialogues.text: Under the covers. Under they go, and soon every layer of clothing emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling her way) Get 'em off. Sandy begins to laugh, and soon Wendy joins him. They roll around on top of each other for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever had a nocturnal emission?

dialogues.text: That's the name for when you wake up and find this little pool of sticky stuff, like after a sexy dream. Sandy shakes his head.

dialogues.text: That's nice. Are you drunk?

dialogues.text: I don't know either. You spin around, when you lie down. Sandy rolls off her and lies on his back.

dialogues.text: I don't think I'm spinning. They cuddle up together. He yawns. She yawns.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SILVER MEADOW. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mikey walks along the edge of the empty pool in the rain. climbs up on the diving board and bounces lightly on it, then gets off and stands, looking down at the pool again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SILVER MEADOW. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mikey walks across the field.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The storm has let up. Mikey walks along. With a running start, he slides on the ice down a hill. He walks back up and slides again, hollering with joy. He an image of a tiny yet absolute and positive freedom. The streetlights sputter on, then off.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS GUEST ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sandy and Wendy lie asleep.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A power line is down. It hisses and HUMS -- a humming ver much like the humming Mikey has been hearing earlier. The humming takes on the same transcendent tonality to wh Mikey has become so accustomed at such moments. Mikey sits down on a metal street guardrail, to ponder th sound and the snaking coil of electricity. A strange look of almost religious wonder overcomes his f as the power line connects to the guardrail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit. Glued by an electrical pulse to the rail, he shakes as th current flows through him. After a minute, his body slumps and slides down the road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: As Paul sits reading on he moving train, the lights insid begin to sputter, and the train begins to slow. After a f moments, the train grinds to a halt, and Paul and his few fellow late night passengers are left in near total dark, with only the light of an emergency exit sign above Paul' head to light the scene. The train is eerily silent.

dialogues.text: Ben drives home.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: An emergency vehicle, lights flashing, crawls by Ben's ca He drives on slowly.

dialogues.text: Jim and Elena arrive on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to come in, get a cup of coffee -- warm up? I can either walk you home, or you could crash in the guest room.

dialogues.text: Sure. Maybe coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone's out. I hope the pipe's -- He walks into the kitchen. The pipes have begun to burst. There's a water leak running down the walls, forming a pu on the floor. Elena has walked into the kitchen behind him. She leans against the counter, picking up the garter belt without thinking for a second, then putting it back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well. Why don't you put on some dry socks -- and we've got some rain boots in the guest closet back there. Last room upstairs -- back of the hall. Elena climbs the stairs in her bare feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elena opens the door, and discovers Wendy and Sandy aslee She stands before the bed, and gazes down on them. They look almost angelic. Wendy, sensing her presence in the room, opens her eyes, slowly coming out of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartbroken, softly) Get dressed. Elena walks out of the room, back to the kitchen. Wendy gets out of bed quietly, leaving Sandy sleeping peacefully. She looks at him lovingly, and tucks the blanket back up around him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS KITCHEN. DAWN
dialogues.text: Elena and Jim are drinking coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should let him sleep. Wendy enters. She looks inquisitively at the two adults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's dad?

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD CAR. DAWN
dialogues.text: Ben continues to drive slowly. He looks out his side wind and sees something. He puts on his brakes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAWN
dialogues.text: Ben gets out of the car, and stands on the top of an icy embankment. In a clump of bushes is the orange glow of a parka. He walks hesitantly toward it. Mike's body lies face down the wet ice. Ben leans down and turns the body over, then stands back amazement and saddened shock. He stands there for a moment, then picks Mike's body up, carrying him over the hill and onto the street. We see no that he is parked just a short block from the Williams's house. He bypasses his car and walks directly down the street to the house. The effort is obviously enormous. He falls fro time to time, then gets back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various passengers asleep. Paul, hunched up in his seat under the faint emergency ex light, cold. He reads his comic book by the light of the emergency exit.

dialogues.text: Suddenly, the lights begin to flicker on and the hum of t train's engines returns. The conductor enters the car, blasting forth in his class nasal train conductor voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning ladies and gentlemen -- On Paul, squinting in the harsh light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILLIAMS KITCHEN. DAWN
dialogues.text: Elena pours Wendy a cup of coffee. They're both in their coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll warm you up. Elena sits next to her. They both raise their cups and si the coffee, not noticing the simultaneity of their moveme

dialogues.speaker: INT. GUEST ROOM. DAWN
dialogues.text: Jim watches the sleeping Sandy, picks up the half-empty bottle of vodka, pours himself a drink. The noise wakes S up. Jim sits down on the bed at his feet and takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? Jim looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. DAWN
dialogues.text: Elena and Wendy hear a hollering from outside, get up to what it is.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WILLIAMS HOUSE. DAWN
dialogues.text: Elena and Wendy come out the front door, as Ben lays Mike body onto the ground before the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben? He's too breathless to speak. They stand there, looking down at Mikey. Behind Elena and Wendy, Jim appears. He pushes softly by them toward the body of his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim -- he was just up --  in Silver Lane -- I think maybe -- a power line -- Jim picks up his son. He carries him silently into the house. Sandy, now standing inside the foyer, pushes himself back against the wall as they pass, without expression. After a moment, from outside, the Hoods can hear Jim's wailing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think? Maybe we should call someone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, we can just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, I don't think he wants us here. Wendy has been watching Sandy through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I -- She turns back up the front steps and gently goes in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on the living room floor, Jim is hugging Mike's body, his shoulders shaking uncontrollably, sobbing. Wendy walks and stands next to Sandy, who is filled momentarily with a brief inexplicable rush of anger towar her -- but she takes him and gives him an awkward, childl hug, then turns and runs out the door, joining Ben and El on the driveway. Sandy watches her go, his face wet with tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you know, for a minute I thought it was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? Yeah. You think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably been waiting all night at the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAWN
dialogues.text: Elena, Wendy, and Ben reach the car and get in. The car starts and drives off. There are more crews out cleaning up the storm's debris a fixing the power lines as they drive.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONRAIL STATION. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: The train slowly pulls in. The Hood family walks down to end of the platform. The train doors open, and Paul, tired and a bit cramped, emerges. He sees his family gathered at the other end of platform, and walks to them. They stand, silent, even dignified, awaiting him. When he joins them they all walk silently to the car and in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOOD CAR. EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Sunlight floods in and temporarily blinds Ben as he start the engine. He squints, his eyes tearing a bit from the light. He looks around, first at his wife, then at his two child sitting in the back seat. He turns off the engine. Quietly, he begins to cry. He turns to the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something -- your mother and I -- have to tell you two -- Elena puts her hand out, almost touching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Ben. Paul looks at Wendy, silently asking her what's happening She casts her eyes downward, as does he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her hand still not yet touching him) Ben.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STATION PARKING LOT. MORNING
dialogues.text: From above: The car, the first morning light shining upon it.
